name: Loom of Fate
desc: A device created by the Abyss Order that is capable of weaving Ley Lines.

customize.text: The Loom of Fate is a device created by the Abyss Order that is capable of weaving Ley Lines. This device was designed to fight the Heavenly Principles, which have been asleep for five hundred years since the cataclysm in Khaenri'ah. In its primitive form, the Loom could only be used to create and implant memories, but as more of it was completed, its power became stronger and stronger. Finally, it now has the power to weave real Ley Lines of its own. Teyvat's Ley Line system is deeply entrenched in the planet, and creating new Ley Lines can neither "replace" nor "extend" the ones that already exist. Once fully completed, the moment it gained the power to weave Ley Lines, it lost the lower-level ability to influence memories. Its full potential is still to be discovered, but it can be a tool that can change the entire world.

The Loom of Fate originates from Chlothar Alberich, a pure-blood noble from Khaenri'ah. It was he who became the founder of the Abyss Order and the Loom of Fate project. Chlothar had a son, Caribert, by a woman from Mondstadt. When the Cataclysm occurred 500 years ago and Celestia cursed the inhabitants of Khaenri'ah, Chlothar received immortality, and his son turned into a Hilichurl and fell into a coma. In an attempt to cure Caribert, the man turned to the Dendro Archon for help, but she did not respond. He later discovered an unknown sanctuary where a
a transcendent being from the Abyss, was located. When Chlothar bowed before him, he felt a sense of awe and joy. Returning home, he gave Caribert a dose of medicine and discovered that his son had woken up and could speak. Chlothar believed that his son could weave his destiny anew now.
<color=#ffffffd9>"Born into abject sorrow, he shall now become the Loom of Fate."</color>

Caribert described the Loom of Fate as extreme sorrow and pain, hope and regret coursing through one's veins, and a degree of Abyssal power that defies comprehension. Chlothar believed that once Caribert possessed all those elements, he would become the Loom of Fate. Caribert was not destined to survive, and even with the power of the "Sinner," he died when he was 8 years old. He did not become the Loom of Fate himself but was used to create it.

customize.text: Eye of the First Field Tiller

The former captain of the Khaenri'ahn royal guard, Dainsleif, known as the "Twilight Sword," tried to stop the Cataclysm, but was unable to prevent the destruction of Khaenri'ah. Doomed to eternal life, he swore to take revenge on the five Sinners of Khaenri'ah who betrayed the nation and stop the Abyss Order that arose from their followers. One day, he and the Traveler discovered a talisman that had been dropped by an Abyss mage. From this talisman, they learned about the first operation of the Loom of Fate. The project itself was related to the inverted statue of the Anemo Archon, which they had previously discovered in the Liyue ruins. During the first phase, the Abyss Order intended to corrupt the mind of Osial, the Overlord of the Vortex, defeated by Rex Lapis during the Archon War, and transform his body using the ancient Khaenri'ah "Field Tiller." The defiled statue of the Archon would become the base to which Osial's limbs would be attached to construct a mechanized god. The new core that would replace the orb usually held by the Statue of the Seven was supposed to be the eye of the very first Field Tiller. The new god was supposed to topple the divine thrones of Celestia.

Field Tiller â€” is the code name for the ancient mechanisms from Khaenri'ah now known as "Ruin Guard." The people there believed that land was not to be tilled with farming tools, but rather to be fought for with steel and blood, and this is how "Field Tiller" came about. After the destruction of Khaenri'ah, the mechanisms lost their masters and went completely out of control. They wandered the lands aimlessly for centuries and eventually scattered throughout Teyvat. To find the first Field Tiller and learn about the inverted statue, the Traveler contacted Barbara, the Deaconess of the Mondstadt church, and she told them about "The Tyrant's Final Fury." Many years ago, balls of fire would rain from the sky whenever anyone approached Old Mondstadt. People at that time believed that it was a curse laid down by the
so they referred to it as "The Tyrant's Final Fury." This strange phenomenon continued for about a year. No one was ever able to solve it, it just gradually ceased on its own. The "The Tyrant's Final Fury" turned out to be the Field Tiller. Many years ago, it accidentally ended up in King of the North Wind's, Andrius, arena, and he mistook the mechanism for a brave man who challenged him. The machine could not think, but every part of it was designed for killing and fighting. It could spin, fly high into the air, and shoot fireballs. In the end, Andrius was able to defeat the machine, but it managed to leave the arena before falling and headed towards the Old Mondstadt. In Stormterror's Lair (Old Mondstadt), Dainsleif and the Traveler discovered the first Field Tiller, and the Twilight Sword hid its eye in his body so that it would not fall into the hands of the Abyss Order.

customize.name: Ruin Guard
customize.desc:
An ancient humanoid war machine.
Legend has it that these machines were combat automatons created by a long-destroyed nation. They now wander ruins and ancient detritus, attacking offending travelers. Research indicates that the Ruin Guards and the ruins they operate in do not originate from the same source, suggesting that there may be a difference of as much as several thousand years between them on the timeline. So why then do the Ruin Guards continue staying among these ruins, using their "explosive firepower" to protect the crumbling walls and broken tiles?

customize.text: Dainsleif continued to investigate matters related to the Loom of Fate. He understood that even when the Abyss Order's plan was disrupted, they found another way to carry out their plans. His main goal was to discover the essence of the Loom of Fate to understand the orderâ€™s true purpose. From the information Dainsleif gathered, it followed that the Loom of Fate was connected to the Ley Lines. The Twilight Sword found out that the activity of the Abyss Order in a certain area was always accompanied by interference in the Ley Lines. His attention was drawn to Vimara Village, where the Traveler was at that time investigating the disappearance of a young man. Although many residents contacted the Adventurers' Guild about his disappearance, no one could remember his name or the place he lived in. The Traveler deduced that this man existed only in the people's memories, which flowed through the Ley Lines.

When Dainsleif realized he had false memories implanted and that the mysterious man was connected to the increasing activity of the Abyss Order near Vimara Village, he decided to send the order on a false trail to meet with the Abyss Order's Princess/Prince. He knew that the order was hunting for the Field Tiller's eye, so he was going to give it to the Traveler so that they could take it out of its hiding place. Dainsleif's plan was disrupted, and he was implanted with false memories that the Field Tiller's eye was already in the Traveler's possession. This is how the Abyss Order was able to obtain the eye and complete the creation of the Loom of Fate.
The mysterious man in people's memories turned out to be Caribert. His consciousness lingered in the mechanism, and he gained the ability to control the device until it was completed. He was not privy to the order's plans regarding the Loom of Fate and did not see the whole picture, but the device helped him achieve his own goal. Many years ago, when Chlothar awakened consciousness in the Hilichurl that his son became with the power of the Abyss, Caribert experienced indescribable horror and pain. To console him, his father told him a story that he found himself in a fairy tale world and took on the form of a little monster. That story allayed Caribert's fears for a moment, so he used the incomplete Loom of Fate to implant a false memory of love into the Hilichurls' minds.

Caribert also used the Loom of Fate to "live" a life that was unjustly taken away. He created his appearance in the image of his father and implanted the memories of the time spent with them in Vimara Village. When the project of the Abyss Order was almost completed, only a thin thread of consciousness remained from Caribert, so he decided to leave the villagers. In the end, he met with the Traveler in the space of his consciousness, where he spoke about the completion of the creation of the Loom of Fate, and disappeared without a trace. In the memories of the villagers, a memory appeared that the missing man met his parents and left with them.
